data.title: Eratosthenes' sieve: Count prime numbers
data.statement:
The goal is to count how many prime numbers are in the range 2 to [[N]].

A prime number is a number greater or equal to 2 which cannot be divided by other numbers than 1 or himself.
For example 2, 3, 5 are prime numbers, but 4 = 2 x 2 is not one. 
So, in range 2 to [[5]], there are 3 prime numbers.   

You may use Eratothenes' sieve to solve this problem (but you can use another algorithm as well if you want). 
This is an algorithm designed by the ancient greek Eratothenes to find prime numbers. 
It starts with a range of numbers from 2 to N. Looping on an increasing current number, it eliminates all multiple of the current number in the range, which are non prime numbers. 
Every number reached that has not previously been eliminated is guaranted to be a prime number.
data.inputDescription: [[N]] : an integer that is the upper limit of the range 2 to [[N]]
data.outputDescription: The count of prime numbers in the range 2 to [[N]]

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

The goal is to count how many prime numbers are in the range 2 to N.

A prime number is a number greater or equal to 2 which cannot be divided by other numbers than 1 or himself.
For example 2, 3, 5 are prime numbers, but 4 = 2 x 2 is not one.
So, in range 2 to 5, there are 3 prime numbers.

You may use Eratothenes' sieve to solve this problem (but you can use another algorithm as well if you want).
This is an algorithm designed by the ancient greek Eratothenes to find prime numbers.
It starts with a range of numbers from 2 to N. Looping on an increasing current number, it eliminates all multiple of the current number in the range, which are non prime numbers.
Every number reached that has not previously been eliminated is guaranted to be a prime number.
Input
N : an integer that is the upper limit of the range 2 to N
Output
The count of prime numbers in the range 2 to N
Constraints
2 ≤ N ≤ 100 000
Example
Input
5
Output
3
